docs.title: Granny square documentation
docs.text:
A granny square is a square piece of crochet with a checkerboard-style pattern, made by crocheting from the centre outward.

A stack of multicoloured granny squares and yarn on top of a granny square blanket. Source: Wikicommons

Granny squares are one of the most common and identifiable crochet projects. They are quick and repetitive to make, and extremely versatile. You can use them and combine them to make blankets, clothes, home furnishings, and any other textile application.

Granny squares introduce many new crochet concepts for beginners, including shaping, colour-changing, and working in the round.

In this documentation:

Page Description Explanation: Introduction to granny squares Understand how granny squares are structured, and what you can use them for. Tutorial: Make a granny square Learn to make a three-row granny square in one solid colour. How-to: How to change colours Make each row of your granny square a different colour. Reference: Granny square glossary Find common granny square crochet terminology.

docs.title: Audience and aims
docs.text:
The intended audience for these docs are beginner crocheters who either want to advance their crochet knowledge, or who have come straight to making granny squares despite it being slightly more advanced (this is very common!). I’ve aimed for an authoritative but reassuring tone, with clear prerequisite information and tightly-scoped explanation.

The goal of these docs is to make a complicated task feel as approachable as possible, and to set realistic expectations that there are likely some new concepts in the task that the user needs to pay attention to.

docs.title: Granny square glossary
docs.text:
These are the common crochet terms you’ll find in this granny square documentation.

This documentation uses US crochet terminology.

Term Abbreviation Description Chain stitch ch A small freestanding stitch, usually used to create empty spaces, or to connect larger stitches. Chain-2 space ch2 sp The empty space under a set of two chain stitches. Double crochet dc The primary crochet stitch in a granny square. Approximately the same height as three chain stitches. Granny cluster - A group of three double crochet stitches. In the round - A style of crochet based on starting in the centre and working outward in a spiral. See Introduction to granny squares for details. Slip stitch sl st A small connecting stitch, usually used to connect yarn to a hook or to a project. Also commonly used to complete a row in projects made in the round. Space sp An empty space in a row of crochet, usually appearing underneath chain stitches or between granny clusters.

docs.title: How to change colours
docs.text:
This how-to guide describes how to change yarn colours for each row.

A three-row granny square, with a different colour for each row Source: Sarah Maker

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
This guide assumes that you already know the following:

  • US crochet terminology (see Granny square glossary)
  • How to make a crochet granny square
  • How to fasten off with an invisible finish

docs.title: Add a row in a different colour
docs.text:
The simplest way to make each row a different colour is to fasten off the old yarn, and start a new row with a new yarn.

  1. When you reach the end of your row, complete the final slip-stitch, then cut your yarn and use an invisible finish.
  2. To join a new row, either:
  3. Slip-stitch the new yarn into any empty space and chain 3 (counts as a double crochet), OR
  4. Make a standing double crochet into any empty space
  5. Complete the granny cluster, then continue working the granny square row as normal.
  6. Complete the row, and weave in any yarn ends.
  7. Repeat these steps as many times as needed.

docs.title: Introduction to granny squares
docs.text:
Learn what what granny squares are, and how they’re structured.

If you’d prefer to start making something, head over to the tutorial Make a crochet granny square.

docs.title: What is a granny square?
docs.text:
A granny square is a piece of crochet made using the granny stitch to create a checkerboard-style mesh square panel. It is crocheted in the round, making it symmetrical on all sides.

  • Granny stitch: A crochet stitch that comprises clusters of 3 double crochets with an empty space between each cluster, to create the famous checkerboard effect.
  • In-the-round crochet: A style of crochet where you create the centre of the piece first, and then work out in concentric circles or spirals, increasing the number of stitches each row.

Crocheters often use many granny squares stitched together, or even just one large granny square.

A blanket made from several small granny squares. Source: Wikicommons

A blanket made from one large granny square. Source: Wikicommons

docs.title: Structure of a granny square
docs.text:
There are three elements of a granny square:

  • Granny clusters: Groups of 3 double crochets.
  • Empty spaces: The empty spaces between granny clusters, made with either 1 chain stitch or no stitches.
  • Corners: An empty space made of 2 or 3 chain stitches.

Each row of a granny square alternates between granny clusters and empty spaces.

This crochet diagram demonstrates their structure:

A diagram of a granny square, using standard crochet diagram symbols. Source: ThisIsCrochet

In the above diagram, the crocheter starts in the centre and works anti-clockwise to make each row. At the end of each row they close the loop, then create three chain stitches to “climb” to the appropriate height to start the next row.

docs.title: Variations
docs.text:
Granny squares are so universal that almost every crocheter has their preferred way to make them. For example:

  • Some crocheters use a continuous piece of yarn to make a granny square, while others prefer to cut and start a new one for each row.
  • Some crocheters make chain stitches between each granny cluster, while others just go straight from one cluster to the next.
  • Some crocheters use 2 chain stitches for corners, while others use 3.

All of these small variations still follow the basic rules of a granny square: that there are granny clusters, empty spaces, and corners.

To learn more about constructing a granny square, see the tutorial Make a crochet granny square.

docs.title: Make a granny square
docs.text:
In this tutorial, you’ll make a crochet granny square with a single colour or skein of yarn.

A yellow crochet granny square with three rows, made using one continuous length of yarn. Source: Sarah Maker

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
This tutorial assumes that you already know the following:

  • US crochet terminology (see Granny square glossary)
  • Chain stitch (ch)
  • Double crochet (dc)
  • Slip stitch (sl st)

You need the following equipment:

  • A cotton or acrylic yarn of your choice (Tip: chunkier yarns are better for learning)
  • A crochet hook at the right size for your yarn (check the yarn label, or use a wraps-per-inch converter tool)
  • A set of stitch markers (you need at least five)

docs.title: Make a crochet granny square
docs.text:
Because this is a beginner tutorial, I’ll provide plain English instructions alongside the standard crochet notation.

Row 0 makes your starting circle.

Row 0: ch 4, sl st into the first chain, put stitch marker in ch4 sp

Plain English:

  1. Make a slip knot to attach the yarn to your crochet hook, and make 4 chains.
  2. Slip-stitch into the first chain you made. This should make a closed circle of 4 chains.
  3. Put a stitch marker in the circle, so that you can identify it later.

Row 1: ch 3 (counts as first dc here and throughout), 2 dc in ch4 sp, [ch 2, 3 dc in ch4 sp] * 3, ch 2, ss to 3rd st in starting ch. (stitches: 12dc, 8ch)

Plain English:

  1. Chain 3. This creates your first double crochet, and gets your working yarn to the right height to create your first row. (Note: Always place a stitch marker in the third chain you make, because you’ll need it later.)
  2. Make 2 double crochets into the circle you made in Row 0. This is different to regular crochet: you’re not crocheting into the stitch, but underneath it. You should now have 3 double crochets in total (known as a “granny cluster”), making the first side of your first square.
  3. Chain 2 (this makes a corner), then make another granny cluster into the circle from Row 0 (this makes another granny cluster).
  4. Repeat step 3 twice more. You should now have 3 corners, and 4 granny clusters.
  5. To make your final corner and close the row, chain 2 and then slip-stitch into the 3rd chain from your original starting stitch.
  6. Lay your piece out flat. You should have 4 granny clusters making up the sides of your square, and 4 chain-2 spaces that make the corners.
  7. Place a stitch marker in each corner, to help you identify them while you work the next row.

Next, let’s make that square bigger. Row 2 works into the chain-2 spaces of Row 1. In each corner, we’ll add a granny cluster, a chain-2 space, and another granny cluster. Remember that you’re always working into the spaces between granny clusters, and not into the granny clusters themselves.

Row 2: ch 3, sk 3dc, [(3dc, ch 2, 3dc) in ch2 sp] * 3, (3dc, ch2, 2dc) in ch2 sp, ss to 3rd st in starting ch3. (stitches: 24dc, 8ch)

Plain English:

  1. Chain 3 and place a stitch marker in the third chain you make. On this row, this chain-3 will be the last double crochet in the final granny cluster you make (this will make more sense in step 5).
  2. In the next chain-2 space, make a granny cluster, then chain 2, then another granny cluster in the same space. This creates your first corner for this round.
  3. Repeat step 2 twice more. You should now have 6 granny clusters, and 3 corners.
  4. To make your final corner and close the row, make a granny cluster in the final chain-2 space, then chain 2, then make 2 more double crochets.
  5. Finally, slip-stitch into the 3rd chain from your original starting stitch. This should complete the final granny cluster.
  6. Lay your piece out flat. You should have 8 granny clusters making up the sides of your square, and 4 chain-2 spaces that make the corners.
  7. Move your stitch markers to the new corners.

Finally, let’s add one more row. Here, you’ll be thinking about sides as well as corners.

Row 3: ch 3, 2 dc in empty sp, (3dc, ch 2, 3dc) in next ch 2 sp, [3dc in empty sp, (3dc, ch 2, 3dc) in next ch 2 sp] * 3, ss to 3rd ch in starting ch3. (stitches: 36dc, 8ch)

Plain English:

  1. Chain 3 and place a stitch marker in the third chain you make. On this row, this chain-3 is the first double crochet in the first granny cluster you make.
  2. In the empty space under your chain-3, make 2 more double crochets. This makes your first granny cluster for this row.
  3. In the next chain-2 space, make a granny cluster, then chain 2, then make another granny cluster. This creates your first corner for this round.
  4. In the next empty space, make a granny cluster.
  5. In the next chain-2 space, make a granny cluster, then chain 2, then make another granny cluster.
  6. Repeat steps 4 and 5 twice more. You should now have 12 granny clusters, and 4 corners.
  7. To close the row, slip-stitch into the 3rd chain from your original starting stitch.
  8. Lay your piece out flat. You should have 12 granny clusters making up the sides of your square, and 4 chain-2 spaces that make the corners.
  9. Move your stitch markers to the new corners.

You’re done! You should have a completed, fully symmetrical granny square with three rows, creating a checkerboard effect.

docs.title: Making your granny square bigger
docs.text:
You can make your granny square as large as you want, as long as you continue to follow the same pattern shown on Row 3, and follow the basic rules:

  • On the sides of your square, make a granny cluster in an empty space, and then skip over to the next empty space.
  • In the corners of your square, make a granny cluster into the chain-2 space, then make 2 chains, then another granny cluster into the same chain-2 space. Then go back to making sides until you reach the next corner.
